"Severe cuts to Medicare and Medicaid and the privatization of Social Security will hurt middle-class and working families, as well as the elderly and the poor. "

It is not clear to me that what is called privatization of social security will hurt the middle class. Most liberals are unaware of the fact that what Bush proposed was that a young worker would HAVE THE OPTION of putting one sixth of her social security contributions into the market rather into the federal budget. This is a rational risk. And Bush made it optional. But his voice was drowned out by Democrats offering their own interpretations of what he intended so that most Democrats do not know the details, only the abuse aimed at Bush.

I myself as professor subscribe to TIAA-CREF. TIAA is like conventional social security. CREF is essentially an investment in carefully chosen stocks. TIAA has shown steady but small growth over the years. But it is CREF, which while suffering from occasional setbacks, is the larger part of my retirement package.

It is foolish for older workers to take the risks which the market brings. But it is equally foolish for younger workers NOT to take that risk, or to be prohibited by Demcrats from BEING ALLOWED to take SOME risk.

Please use some common sense.

First of all there are not enough votes in congress....and never will be....to privataze social security. Bush tried this in 2001 when he had the House and the Senate and he got it shoved down his throat. So stop fear-mongering.

Second,Ryan's reform of medicare does NOT apply to anyone over 55; today's seniors will not be touched under the Ryan plan. Ironically, Obamacare pulls $700B (over ten years) OUT of medicare...starting immediately. I don't recall any shrieks of protest from the Left over this.

The key issue is to grow the economy which will lower unemployment and keep inflation in check. The problem the Left has is that they're TERRIFIED that a growing economy will distribute its gains to people they don't like. They would rather see a stagnant economy with high unemployment, rather than see the rich get richer.

Rohit, don't worry. Younger workers can "profit" from the "freedom" to have their retirements in 401-Ks so the wonder-workers on Wall Street can play with them. Just as many of the elders did, too.

And good luck with that.

Romney and Ryan say that they want to restore prosperity-- but for whom?

Severe cuts to Medicare and Medicaid and the privatization of Social Security will hurt middle-class and working families, as well as the elderly and the poor.

The upper brackets are doing just fine, but Romney and Ryan would lavish more largesse on them. If this created jobs and economic revival it might be worth it, but there is no evidence that tax cuts induce economic expansion.

The weight of the evidence is that aggregate demand-- that is, the purchase of goods and services-- creates economic activity and jobs, and that federal spending is needed to generate such demand. Tax cuts can play a role, but are less effective because a portion of tax cuts are saved.

If elected, it is clear that Romney and Ryan will be very, very good for the wealthy. The middle-class, the working-class, the elderly and the poor will be fighting for scraps.

Digital Penguin, New Hope, PA:

The ACA generates revenue from two primary sources: Mandate penalty payments and an excise tax on "Cadillac" plans. Couple these with simply cutting payments to doctors, and you have what the president described as "lowering the cost curve".

It doesn't take a policy wonk to understand that making payment cuts to doctors, one-third of whom are already refusing to take Medicare patients, is not a viable long-term solution.

In the end, though, it always comes down to increased taxes (a/k/a penalties) and decreased spending, which is what Americans are quite capable of grasping without reading the ACA in detail.

I read Cosmo avidly from the time I was 19 until Bonnie Fuller took over. Under HGB, the magazine was sexy and saucy and told women how important work was when other magazines were still giving recipes and telling you the best way to make your floors shine.

Helen Gurley Brown was a feminist. She supported the ERA and abortion rights. She was an ardent supporter of Hillary Rodham Clinton when she was running for the Senate in New York. She didn't quite "get" sexual harassment or the dangers of AIDS and in the end -- I think that was what hurt the magazine.

I spoke to her on the phone several times. She loved talking to her readers and she was wonderful to talk to and instead of my interviewing her -- she always ended up interviewing me. She did that to the writer of Vanity Fair. She did that with everyone.

If she can't be pigeonholed as a typical feminist -- so what? She told women that they didn't have to stay virgins at a time when no one said that and not to depend on a man for financial security. She always assumed that a woman would go on working and earning after she was married

I respected and liked Helen Gurley Brown enormously even if I didn't always agree with her. She was one of a kind. RIP.

"Do you believe that - in statistically significant, i.e. not anecdotal way..."

I copied that from one of your myriad of comments below.

How DARE you mention statistical significance. In your comment above, you suggest that there is some sort of causation between HGB and divorce rates. You don't even cite a test of correlation, much less one of causation, which isn't statistically possible. Yet you make the assertion that there is a causation anyway and then post on another comment about "statistical significance."

Besides your incredible hypocrisy, let me just say that YOU'RE A MAN and have NO IDEA what could lead to sustained happiness in a woman (for that matter, most women don't either. Because we're ALL DIFFERENT and can't be generalized).

Divorce rates went up in the 80s for 2 reasons:
1. Society had been telling women for centuries that the most valuable thing they could do was to get married. So they got married as quickly as they could find a man.

2. Suddenly, in the 80s/90s, it became socially acceptable to divorce. So now all those women who married men they didn't actually love could get out of the marriage (there actually have been studies published in peer-reviewed journals on this topic).

Sorry if female sexuality scares you, but it's not going away. Plenty of women have successful, meaningful lives that involve also enjoying sex for the sake of sex.

You have to get over yourself. Why should anyone have to defend HGB's impact on the generations of women she influenced with "scientific" studies that "prove women are happier". In the realm of the personal, women who say their lives were changed for the better are all the evidence you need to evaluate whether their lives were changed for the better.

The ample evidence in the comments section of this obit shows that there are still plenty of people who feel threatened by sex, and particularly, sexuality in women. Surely that number is lower and lower every year, at least I hope so, but our puritan roots are still with us.

Divorce rates being high is only evidence that marriage is unsustainable in most cases as a lifetime commitment. That women have been empowered to escape a bad marriage is a positive social outcome, not a negative one. You sound like you'd want to keep them chained to a bad marriage just for the purposes of keeping the statistics down.

Trying to pin the relative historical "happiness" of women on the impact of HGB is a silly exercise and impossible to determine with any meaningful conclusions. The empirical evidence is pretty substantial that HGB gave attention to how women, and their sexuality, were being repressed in the Mad Med era, and for many, provided a blueprint for enjoying a more liberated existence. Net net, win win.

A scientific study? Give me a break. People are enjoying sharing their thoughts and recollections about HGB, which (as you can see) vary quite a bit from person to person. I hardly think you can deny she was extremely influential.

Are we not allowed to talk about deceased public figures, unless we can prove with some study that they improved human happiness by a certain percentage? Did (for example) Albert Einstein's life improve human happiness? The atomic bomb couldn't have been developed without his work.

On a related note, you failed to provide any actual evidence that HGB was linked in any way with increased divorce rates. Causation fail.

OK, OK. Are we allowed to be a bit rational even when a fellow human being (and certainly a celebrity to some) departed? Or is it indeed expected to compete in lavishing a praise on Ms. Brown ("thanks to you millions of women know how to enjoy sex", etc.)?

Are there any (objective, scientific) studies and consensus that say since advent of G-B Cosmopolitan etc. women are happier? For that matter: Are with hopefully happier, more Sex-In-the City self-fulfilled women are also marriages and committed relationships and minor children in them happier?

G-d gave us a Torah, or set of laws, to teach us how to live in peace with each other and know our Creator.

When one amongst us, especially of our own, makes a travesty of this law, subverts it, perverts it, it is an offense not only to humankind but to the Author who gave it.

That is why, as a Jew, I must speak out against the kind of person I see Sheldon Adelson as. One whose crass and ill-gotten gains have fed a war machine through sleazy back room deals against the laws of this country, and for what? So he can finance a would-be President who will be content to permit if not lead Israel to start World War III?

I am much more concerned for Adelson than the "little man in the street" who has neither the wherewithal nor the inclination to do harm on such a large scale, whether that man be black, white, Asian, or gay. But when I see a "fat cat" like Adelson intent on doing WHAT I PERCEIVE as the world harm, I must take a principled stand against moronic, selfish and stupid behavior.

Do we know all the answers? Does each one of us have the Cliff Notes to the denouement of this play?

In my opinion, the end results, or product of this play are irrelevant. It is simply the ethical procedures one follows, and with what competence and integrity, that we will be judged. The ends do not justify the means and never have. All is in G-d's hands, but it is up to man to seal his fate.
